intro: Bellevalia hispida, commonly known as the hairy bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Campanulaceae family. It is native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa, typically growing in rocky or gravelly soils. The plant features hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, with bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple. It blooms in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Bellevalia hispida is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in dry, sunny conditions.
